Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Robust High-Performance Organic Electro-Optic Materials
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I Project is to enable large-scale integration of photonic and electronic components in computing and communications systems. Optical computing represents the a potential path forward in the expansion of computing power. Hybrid devices utilizing organic electro-optic (OEO) materials are a potential enabling technology for electronic-photonic digital computing (EPDC), with further applications in telecommunications, quantum computing, and quantum networking. Compared to existing silicon photonics and microwave photonics systems, hybrid electro-optics deliver critical performance enhancements, with potential for improved capabilities and lower operating costs for computing and 5G telecommunications systems. The growth of EPDC will also reduce power consumption and carbon footprints of high-performance computing and cloud computing, especially intensive applications such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, where operations are particularly conducive to being performed optically.<br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project directly addresses key challenges in bringing high-performance hybrid organic electro-optic (OEO) components capable of direct integration with conventional silicon-based semiconductor technologies to market. Hybrid devices utilizing OEO materials have demonstrated significant advantages in speed, size, and power consumption compared to existing technologies. However, rigorous definition of materials properties, optimization of long-term thermal and photostability, and ability to translate new OEO material concepts into commercial materials are essential for establishing market viability. This project includes evaluating stability and encapsulation techniques to ensure long-term reliability and commercial-scale synthesis of a next-generation material for commercial applications, translating recent academic developments from theory aided design into a commercial supply chain. These results will de-risk adoption of hybrid OEO-based technologies and enable a wider range of applications via higher performance and better understanding of thermal constraints and encapsulation requirements.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efficient data transport infrastructure, whether over fiber or wireless, is increasingly crucial across nearly all aspects of society. Semiconductor photonics technologies have allowed bringing high-speed communication using light to our homes and workplaces, as well as the datacenters and cellular networks that support the wide range of devices that we interact with in the era of ubiquitous computing. However, further scaling of bandwidth and power efficiency requires improvements in electrical to optical signal conversion.

This Phase I Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project focused on improving electrical to optical signal conversion (electro-optic modulation) using engineered organic materials intended to be utilized in hybrid devices on silicon photonics or other semiconductor photonics platforms. While organic materials have previously demonstrated very high electro-optic (EO) modulation efficiencies, obtaining a combination of high thermal stability against the demanding temperature ranges expected in datacenters or vehicles alongside high performance has previously proved challenging.

The first major technical goal of the project was rigorous thermal and environmental stability testing on an organic electro-optic (OEO) material called HLD, developed at the University of Washington and commercialized by NLM Photonics. Over a series of 2000 hour accelerated aging tests, our team demonstrated that the electro-optic activity of HLD is long-term stable at high temperatures, with no degradation observed at the Telcordia benchmark temperature of 85°C and a projected lifetime (time to 80% performance) of over 11 years at 120°C. Environmental stability tests against oxygen and humidity at high temperatures were also performed to define packaging requirements; our team determined that expected packaging requirements for HLD were approximately two orders of magnitude less stringent than those for organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs), which would enable ready adaptation of current electronic and photonics packaging technologies.

The second major technical goal of the project involved utilization of the same chemical approach demonstrated with HLD in a higher-performance material. In this approach, first a mixture of two active organic molecules (chromophores) are deposited from solvent and dried, and second the chromophores undergo a heat-driven reaction during processing that locks in alignment and provides excellent thermal and chemical stability while also enabling a high density of chromophores for high performance. This approach utilized a new chromophore core with record EO performance; the resulting material, called BAHX demonstrated over double the performance of HLD combined with high thermal stability; further demonstrating the efficacy of the approach. This new material can enable even smaller devices operating at lower voltages, and has already been demonstrated in a prototype fiber transmitter.

Other accomplishments during the project included evaluating and demonstrating viability of using OEO materials for quantum applications, in which tolerance of cryogenic temperatures and low loss are required, and construction of photonic test infrastructure at the University of Washington for both academic and commercial use. Broader impacts of the project included supporting training of a postdoctoral fellow, shorter-term involvement by two graduate students, and one undergraduate summer intern, as well as communication of results via multiple peer-reviewed papers, conference proceedings, presentations at national conferences, and initial commercial offering of devices using NLM’s HLD via Polariton Technologies, a Swiss startup developing high-bandwidth plasmonic-organic hybrid photonic components.

The results obtained under this project demonstrated the ability to synthesize OEO materials with high performance and resistance to demanding conditions, and, working with commercial partners and translational research fabs, high viability for integration of these materials in photonics platforms. The project further demonstrated effective technology transfer of work with a long history of federal support (including NSF) to a commercial technology that provides an important tool for the semiconductor industry building the communications and computing infrastructure of the future.

Modified by: Lewis E Johnson

Semiconductor photonics technologies have allowed bringing high-speed communication using light to our homes and workplaces, as well as the datacenters and cellular networks that support the wide range of devices that we interact with in the era of ubiquitous computing.
